question.input_text: I arrived at the shop <item>to find that</item> the door was locked.
option: The speaker couldn’t remember whether she had locked the door of the shop, and went back to check.
The speaker was expecting the door of the shop to be unlocked when she arrived, but it wasn’t.
question.answer: The speaker was expecting the door of the shop to be unlocked when she arrived, but it wasn’t.

exercise.rubric: Are these sentences possible: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: Can you arrange <item>for the gold to be delivered</item> on Friday?
I need <item>for you to help</item> me.
She asked <item>for the designs to be sent</item> to her office.
We’d like <item>for you to stay</item> as long as you want.
She hates <item>for people to feel</item> sad.

feedback.desc:
113.7
A and C are normal.
B, D and E are also possible in informal American English.

question.text: What do you feel about these two sentences?
question.input_text:
It’s important for there to be a fire escape at the back of the building.
It’s important that there should be a fire escape at the back of the building.

feedback.desc:
113.10
B is perhaps a little more formal.
